JOHNS HOPKINS UNIVERSITY
VOL. XVIII, NO. 23.

BALTIMORE, MD., APRIL 20, 1914.

PRICE, FIVE CENTS

WHAT'S THAT? PUSHBALL!!

PORTER LEADS IN SLAUGHTER

NAVY WINS MEET BY FIVE POINTS

KNIPP AND HUCK BEAT HARVARD

We Thought it a Joke at First, But
They Really Mean to Have It.
On With the Dance.

Varsity Ball Players Find V.M.I. Pitchers
Easy "Pickings," and Fatten Up
Their Batting Averages.

Varsity Track and Field Men Lose at
Annapolis in Heart-Breaking Finish.
Pole Vault Decided Winner.

Varsity's Spectacular "Johnnies" Lead in
Saturday's Lacrosse Fight—Return
Game Will Be a Hummer.

All hail the freshman-sophomore
PUSH BALL contest!
The decorous Student Council,
revolting at the frightful annual
hazing casualties, has finally hit
Upon a novel outlet for class rivalry.
Next Saturday afternoon, at 2.30
o'clock sharp, two stalwart teams,
each made up of twenty-five chosen
braves from the sophomore and
freshman classes, will take the field
'arrayed in fitting costume, and push
a great big ball around until the
seniors have their fill of laughter.
The contest has been made possible through the kindness of Washington and Lee, which loaned Hopkins a push-ball, about ten feet in
diameter, and made of rhinoceros
hide. The event will be financed
by the Athletic Association, and
bids fair to create a furore in academic circles.
The object is to push the giant
sphere from the middle of the field
over goal lines marked off at each
end. The science of the contest
consists in so spinning, twisting and
otherwise tangoing the ball that the
Opposing team shall be either lifted
high into the air or trampled under
foot.
The belligerent classes will choose
captains the early part of this week.
The leaders will then immediately
select teams and issue calls for
practice. Of course, the entire student body is worked up to fever
heat over the struggle, and expects
to march out to Homewood en
masse; for just think of it!—staid
old Hopkins is going to play at
pushball! Upon the success of this
year's game depends its becoming
an annual contest, which perhaps
will become tradition.

Virginia Military Institute was
no match for the 'Varsity nine on
Saturday and lost out, 16 to 2.
.In eight innings Hopkins' players
made eighteen hits and got eight
bases on balls. The fact that only
two men were stranded on the
sacks shows that Coach Hooper's
charges made the best of their opportunities.
Capt. Pete Porter had a wonderful day—he made five runs, drew
three bases on balls, got to first on
an error and batted out a double.
His catch of L. McCormick's hot
liner in the ninth was one of the
features of the game.
The Virginians had not expected
to be treated so badly at Homewood. They had just come from a
close game with St. John's, and had
figured in a ii-to-6 game with Virginia.
Booker was the first pitcher they
sent to the mound. In the first
inning he gave Porter a base and
allowed two singles and a double
to follow. Before he had retired
a hand he was called from the box
and Watt, chief of the Lexington
staff, sent in. Watt was not able
to stop the walloping, and the
afternoon was turned into an
old-fashioned "swat-fest," in which
Hopkins piled up runs as fast as
it could get men on the bases.
The Southerners did notlose heart,
but played as if Hopkins had but
a one-run margin. The game was
replete with sensational plays, and
the ninth inning was a hair raiser
in this respect. In the Hopkins half
Capt. Pete Porter, who was on
third, worked the squeeze play with
Worthington.
When the Virginians came to bat,
Gillespie sent a high fly to right
that Williams caught off the hedge
fence. Sewell duplicated the hit,
but Williams could not duplicate
his catch. The Hopkins right
fielder, however, nabbed Sewell before he reached second base on a
beautiful peg from deep right. The
third hand was retired by Porter's
flying stab and fall with L. McCormick's liner.
Coach Hooper enjoyer the contest immensely. It was the first
game at Homewood which was not
attended by the Hopkins "jinx,"
and there was not a moment of tension or worry for the Black and
Blue following.
The game put the large crowd in
an excellent humor for the Harvard

Hopkins lost the dual meet with
Navy on Saturday at Annapolis by
five points. The score was 46Y,
to 4I2.
Until the last event — the pole
vault—the teams were even, and
neither had been able to forge ahead
by any great margin. Navy captured both places in the vault, however, and the Black and Blue was
downed in the first of its outdoor
activities of the season.
Although Navy won, it did not
have the star performer on its side.
Harry Wagner—Mercury of the
Y. M. C. A.—took first place in
both the mo and 220 yard dashes—
the two prettiest events of the
games.
The summary of events:

Harvard's splendid lacrosse team
battled with determination to overcome the 'Varsity twelve on Saturday,.but Coach Wolfe's men, showing unexpected form, won out,
to 3.
No lacrosse team in the Intercollegiate League could have downed
Hopkins Saturday. There was obvious teamwork, splendid endurance, individual excellence and,
finally, a scrappy determination that
no collegiate twelve in the country
could have equalled.
Harvard lost, and it was a bitter
pill. As soon as Huck had put the
Hopkins team in the lead, the Crimson almost in a state of desperation, began to fight harder for possession of the ball and, in doing
so, partly lost the excellent organization it had shown at the beginning of the game. Scrappy play
became the order, but Hopkins met
it without much effort, and Referee
Stockton Matthews of Swarthmore
was continually reprimanding players of both teams.
Johnny Huck and Johnny Knipp,
the largest and smallest players on
the field, respectively, were the undisputed leaders in the victory.
Huck put Hopkins in the lead with
two goals in the opening minutes
of play, and Knipp, the wonderful
little first attack, was directly responsible for subsequent charges
on the Harvard net that piled up
the Black and Blue points and
threw Harvard on the defense.
Nearly every 'Varsity player
shone at his position—notably Capt.
Butts Sutton, Tommy Troxell, Leibensperger, Randall and Hollyday.
While the coaches had confidence
in the team, they did not expect
such a decisive victory. They were
almost as surprised as Harvard.
The game was delayed for nearly
an hour because the Cambridge
sticks had been lost. It was later
discovered that the porter who had
them in charge had stopped in
Philadelphia to watch a workhorse parade and had missed his
Baltimore connection. Just like the
"Sleepy City"! For nine minutes
of the first half Harvard used Hopkins' sticks, their own having then
arrived by auto truck.
The Crimson was manifestly disappointed at defeat. The men had
not expected it, and that it was
so heavily administered added to
their sorrow. Harvard, however,
promises a hard return battle later
in the season at Cambridge, but if

1913 Holds First Reunion.

The Class of 1913, last year's
seniors, held its first feunion on
Saturday night, April ii, at the
Emerson Hotel in the form of a
banquet.
George M. Gillet, Jr., was toastmaster. The following were the
toasts and speakers: "Unveiling of
the Dean's Portrait," Augustus E.
Sattler ; "Homewood and the New
President," Paul 0. Carter; "Dead
Ones," Leo Brady; "The University," Julian D. Sears; "The Elusive Bone," Charles Leland Getz;
"Culture," Edmond S. Donoho.
The committee was composed of
C. L. Getz (chairman), Lynn W.
Meekins (secretary), Louis L. Jacobs, Julian H. Marshall, George
M. Gillet, Jr., Gabriel E. Porter and
J. Edward Richardson, Jr.

The Grotius Society, at its meeting on March 31, selected its team
to meet Zelosophic of Pennsylvania
in the third annual debate on Friday night in Philadelphia.
The subject of the debate will be:
"Resolved, that the President of the
United States should be nominated
by direct primaries; instead of by
a party convention as at present."
Hopkins will have the affirmative,
and not the negative, as was previously announced.
The try-outs for the debate were
exceedingly interesting and keen.
The Socitty turned out almost to
a man, and it was difficult to make
a selection. Finally, after a prolonged consultation, the team was
chosen as follows : Tingley' (chairman), Nachlas, Schaffer and Uhler
(alternate). The adviser of the
team has not been chosen. Candidates for the position have been requested to prepare short papers on
the question to be debated and present them before the chairman.
The team will go to Philadelph:a
on Friday and will be entertained
lw the Zelosophic Society. They
will probably remain there over
Saturday, to be present at the University of Pennsylvania Relays, in
wh:ch Hopkins will compete..

onday, I av 4—"Troilus.

The girl was attempting to dance
with a fat man at a tango tea. The
fat man was a great bungler, and
he knew it. He gasped, as they
hobbled about to the strains of
"Every Little Movement."
"It's awfully kind of you to
dance with me — me, the worst
dancer in the room !"
Then he trod on her foot for the
sixth time, and the girl replied:
"Oh, how can you say so? Why,
you hardly seem to touch the floor!"

—Ex. ,

do not understand the reason *for
its coming. The only rational ex-

cuse is that it may promote a more
refined spirit of rivalry; that it will
prevent such "parties" as that of
last autumn, which had a stationhouse scene as a climax. If this,
then, is the ultimate goal, why not
choose sides for a good old round
of "Clap In and Clap Out," and
have the freshmen kissing sophomore beauties as the epitome of
class friendship and tender rivalry.
There has been no marked enthusiasm in either class over the
PUSH BALL battle. The men are accepting it as something prescribed
by the Student Council. We are,
however, very anxious to see the
game successfully staged. We hold
that the under classes should respect the authority and guidance
of the Council. But next year we
should favor adherence to the University's traditions—we mean the
cane and class rushes—the events
that the sophomore$ and upper
classmen alike wanted to schedule
last fall. Then, too, what has become of the freshman-sophomore
baseball and lacrosse games? It
would be far better to retain the
old customs and develop them, if
necessary, along newer lines than
to introduce fads and foibles that
may ultimately lead to the disappearance of proper class rivalry and
tradition.
The Harvard Lampoon recently
printed the following, which is
apropos our situation:
"'17—What happened at the Student Board meeting last night?
"'i6—Oh, they shattered another
tradition."

Every man in the University is
familiar with the situation and,
what is more, tolerates it. He
should remember, h-,wever, that
class poverty cannot be alleviated
nor a Hullabaloo printed unless
every individual pays his class dues.
And, too, he must do this regularly.
It is better to contribute monthly
than to face separation from a
young fortune in the senior year.
Hopkins classes must awaken
from financial lethargy.

I LECTURES OF THE PAST WEEK
Phoenicians Penciled Their Eye-brows.

Not even milady's vanity bag is
a modern creation, but was in use
among the eye-brow penciled and
languorous Phoenician beauties
thousands of years ago, according
to Frank Edward Johnson, officier
de l'Academie de France, officier
du Nichan Iftikar, who spoke on
Tuesday in McCoy Hall before the
Archeological Institute on "The
Phoenician, Roman and Byzantine
Ruins of Africa (Tunisia)."
The Phoenicians were also way
ahead of us in the art of hardening gold, according to Mr. Johnson, who said that their.process had
died out or had been lost with them.
Finger rings were as popular then
as they are now and Mr. Johnson
showed a ring that had been dug up
in ruins in the section where formerly the Phoenicians were lords
and masters. Numerous pictures
showing Roman architecture and
highways, denoting the spread of
the Roman Empire over Northern
Africa, were shown.
For the greater part of the last
five years Mr. Johnson has been
engaged in original research, exploration and archxological work
in Tunisia.

Penn. an Easy Mark.

Pennsylvania was easily outclassed by Hopkins on Saturday,
April ii, at Homewood—the score
being 12 to I.
Penn is a newcomer at the Indian game, this being its second
season on the field. Taking this
fact into consideration, its squad
made a good showing.
Troxell shot'the first goal after
about a minute of play, and in the
first half Hopkins kept up a fusillade of shots that resulted in eleven
goals.
Only once did the visitors shoot
the ball past Goalkeeper Sears.
Leslie Tattersall, a Baltimore boy
at Penn, made the lone tally.
Hopkins did not play offensively
in .the second period. A number of

JOHNS HOPKINS UNIVERSITY
VOL. XVIII, NO. 23.

BALTIMORE, MD., APRIL 20, 1914.

PRICE, FIVE CENTS

WHAT'S THAT? PUSHBALL!!

PORTER LEADS IN SLAUGHTER

NAVY WINS MEET BY FIVE POINTS

KNIPP AND HUCK BEAT HARVARD

We Thought it a Joke at First, But
They Really Mean to Have It.
On With the Dance.

Varsity Ball Players Find V.M.I. Pitchers
Easy "Pickings," and Fatten Up
Their Batting Averages.

Varsity Track and Field Men Lose at
Annapolis in Heart-Breaking Finish.
Pole Vault Decided Winner.

Varsity's Spectacular "Johnnies" Lead in
Saturday's Lacrosse Fight—Return
Game Will Be a Hummer.

All hail the freshman-sophomore
PUSH BALL contest!
The decorous Student Council,
revolting at the frightful annual
hazing casualties, has finally hit
Upon a novel outlet for class rivalry.
Next Saturday afternoon, at 2.30
o'clock sharp, two stalwart teams,
each made up of twenty-five chosen
braves from the sophomore and
freshman classes, will take the field
'arrayed in fitting costume, and push
a great big ball around until the
seniors have their fill of laughter.
The contest has been made possible through the kindness of Washington and Lee, which loaned Hopkins a push-ball, about ten feet in
diameter, and made of rhinoceros
hide. The event will be financed
by the Athletic Association, and
bids fair to create a furore in academic circles.
The object is to push the giant
sphere from the middle of the field
over goal lines marked off at each
end. The science of the contest
consists in so spinning, twisting and
otherwise tangoing the ball that the
Opposing team shall be either lifted
high into the air or trampled under
foot.
The belligerent classes will choose
captains the early part of this week.
The leaders will then immediately
select teams and issue calls for
practice. Of course, the entire student body is worked up to fever
heat over the struggle, and expects
to march out to Homewood en
masse; for just think of it!—staid
old Hopkins is going to play at
pushball! Upon the success of this
year's game depends its becoming
an annual contest, which perhaps
will become tradition.

Virginia Military Institute was
no match for the 'Varsity nine on
Saturday and lost out, 16 to 2.
.In eight innings Hopkins' players
made eighteen hits and got eight
bases on balls. The fact that only
two men were stranded on the
sacks shows that Coach Hooper's
charges made the best of their opportunities.
Capt. Pete Porter had a wonderful day—he made five runs, drew
three bases on balls, got to first on
an error and batted out a double.
His catch of L. McCormick's hot
liner in the ninth was one of the
features of the game.
The Virginians had not expected
to be treated so badly at Homewood. They had just come from a
close game with St. John's, and had
figured in a ii-to-6 game with Virginia.
Booker was the first pitcher they
sent to the mound. In the first
inning he gave Porter a base and
allowed two singles and a double
to follow. Before he had retired
a hand he was called from the box
and Watt, chief of the Lexington
staff, sent in. Watt was not able
to stop the walloping, and the
afternoon was turned into an
old-fashioned "swat-fest," in which
Hopkins piled up runs as fast as
it could get men on the bases.
The Southerners did notlose heart,
but played as if Hopkins had but
a one-run margin. The game was
replete with sensational plays, and
the ninth inning was a hair raiser
in this respect. In the Hopkins half
Capt. Pete Porter, who was on
third, worked the squeeze play with
Worthington.
When the Virginians came to bat,
Gillespie sent a high fly to right
that Williams caught off the hedge
fence. Sewell duplicated the hit,
but Williams could not duplicate
his catch. The Hopkins right
fielder, however, nabbed Sewell before he reached second base on a
beautiful peg from deep right. The
third hand was retired by Porter's
flying stab and fall with L. McCormick's liner.
Coach Hooper enjoyer the contest immensely. It was the first
game at Homewood which was not
attended by the Hopkins "jinx,"
and there was not a moment of tension or worry for the Black and
Blue following.
The game put the large crowd in
an excellent humor for the Harvard

Hopkins lost the dual meet with
Navy on Saturday at Annapolis by
five points. The score was 46Y,
to 4I2.
Until the last event — the pole
vault—the teams were even, and
neither had been able to forge ahead
by any great margin. Navy captured both places in the vault, however, and the Black and Blue was
downed in the first of its outdoor
activities of the season.
Although Navy won, it did not
have the star performer on its side.
Harry Wagner—Mercury of the
Y. M. C. A.—took first place in
both the mo and 220 yard dashes—
the two prettiest events of the
games.
The summary of events:

Harvard's splendid lacrosse team
battled with determination to overcome the 'Varsity twelve on Saturday,.but Coach Wolfe's men, showing unexpected form, won out,
to 3.
No lacrosse team in the Intercollegiate League could have downed
Hopkins Saturday. There was obvious teamwork, splendid endurance, individual excellence and,
finally, a scrappy determination that
no collegiate twelve in the country
could have equalled.
Harvard lost, and it was a bitter
pill. As soon as Huck had put the
Hopkins team in the lead, the Crimson almost in a state of desperation, began to fight harder for possession of the ball and, in doing
so, partly lost the excellent organization it had shown at the beginning of the game. Scrappy play
became the order, but Hopkins met
it without much effort, and Referee
Stockton Matthews of Swarthmore
was continually reprimanding players of both teams.
Johnny Huck and Johnny Knipp,
the largest and smallest players on
the field, respectively, were the undisputed leaders in the victory.
Huck put Hopkins in the lead with
two goals in the opening minutes
of play, and Knipp, the wonderful
little first attack, was directly responsible for subsequent charges
on the Harvard net that piled up
the Black and Blue points and
threw Harvard on the defense.
Nearly every 'Varsity player
shone at his position—notably Capt.
Butts Sutton, Tommy Troxell, Leibensperger, Randall and Hollyday.
While the coaches had confidence
in the team, they did not expect
such a decisive victory. They were
almost as surprised as Harvard.
The game was delayed for nearly
an hour because the Cambridge
sticks had been lost. It was later
discovered that the porter who had
them in charge had stopped in
Philadelphia to watch a workhorse parade and had missed his
Baltimore connection. Just like the
"Sleepy City"! For nine minutes
of the first half Harvard used Hopkins' sticks, their own having then
arrived by auto truck.
The Crimson was manifestly disappointed at defeat. The men had
not expected it, and that it was
so heavily administered added to
their sorrow. Harvard, however,
promises a hard return battle later
in the season at Cambridge, but if

1913 Holds First Reunion.

The Class of 1913, last year's
seniors, held its first feunion on
Saturday night, April ii, at the
Emerson Hotel in the form of a
banquet.
George M. Gillet, Jr., was toastmaster. The following were the
toasts and speakers: "Unveiling of
the Dean's Portrait," Augustus E.
Sattler ; "Homewood and the New
President," Paul 0. Carter; "Dead
Ones," Leo Brady; "The University," Julian D. Sears; "The Elusive Bone," Charles Leland Getz;
"Culture," Edmond S. Donoho.
The committee was composed of
C. L. Getz (chairman), Lynn W.
Meekins (secretary), Louis L. Jacobs, Julian H. Marshall, George
M. Gillet, Jr., Gabriel E. Porter and
J. Edward Richardson, Jr.

The Grotius Society, at its meeting on March 31, selected its team
to meet Zelosophic of Pennsylvania
in the third annual debate on Friday night in Philadelphia.
The subject of the debate will be:
"Resolved, that the President of the
United States should be nominated
by direct primaries; instead of by
a party convention as at present."
Hopkins will have the affirmative,
and not the negative, as was previously announced.
The try-outs for the debate were
exceedingly interesting and keen.
The Socitty turned out almost to
a man, and it was difficult to make
a selection. Finally, after a prolonged consultation, the team was
chosen as follows : Tingley' (chairman), Nachlas, Schaffer and Uhler
(alternate). The adviser of the
team has not been chosen. Candidates for the position have been requested to prepare short papers on
the question to be debated and present them before the chairman.
The team will go to Philadelph:a
on Friday and will be entertained
lw the Zelosophic Society. They
will probably remain there over
Saturday, to be present at the University of Pennsylvania Relays, in
wh:ch Hopkins will compete..

Harvard University, on "The Poetry of Chaucer," will be :
Monday, April 27—"The Times
and the Man."
Wednesday, April 29—"The Book
of the Duchess."
Friday, May 1--The House of

onday, I av 4—"Troilus.

the hour. The door will be closed
when the lecturer begins.

scholars in America. Although

The girl was attempting to dance
with a fat man at a tango tea. The
fat man was a great bungler, and
he knew it. He gasped, as they
hobbled about to the strains of
"Every Little Movement."
"It's awfully kind of you to
dance with me — me, the worst
dancer in the room !"
Then he trod on her foot for the
sixth time, and the girl replied:
"Oh, how can you say so? Why,
you hardly seem to touch the floor!"

—Ex. ,

There has been no marked enthusiasm in either class over the
PUSH BALL battle. The men are accepting it as something prescribed
by the Student Council. We are,
however, very anxious to see the
game successfully staged. We hold
that the under classes should respect the authority and guidance
of the Council. But next year we
should favor adherence to the University's traditions—we mean the
cane and class rushes—the events
that the sophomore$ and upper
classmen alike wanted to schedule

baseball and lacrosse games? It
would be far better to retain the
old customs and develop them, if
necessary, along newer lines than
to introduce fads and foibles that
may ultimately lead to the disappearance of proper class rivalry and
tradition.

printed the following, which is
apropos our situation:

tradition."

ad commissions to get funds. He
does everything but steal.
Every man in the University is
familiar with the situation and,
what is more, tolerates it. He
should remember, h-,wever, that
class poverty cannot be alleviated
nor a Hullabaloo printed unless
every individual pays his class dues.
And, too, he must do this regularly.
It is better to contribute monthly
than to face separation from a
young fortune in the senior year.
Hopkins classes must awaken
from financial lethargy.

I LECTURES OF THE PAST WEEK
Phoenicians Penciled Their Eye-brows.

Not even milady's vanity bag is
a modern creation, but was in use
among the eye-brow penciled and
languorous Phoenician beauties
thousands of years ago, according
to Frank Edward Johnson, officier
de l'Academie de France, officier
du Nichan Iftikar, who spoke on
Tuesday in McCoy Hall before the
Archeological Institute on "The
Phoenician, Roman and Byzantine
Ruins of Africa (Tunisia)."
The Phoenicians were also way
ahead of us in the art of hardening gold, according to Mr. Johnson, who said that their.process had
died out or had been lost with them.
Finger rings were as popular then
as they are now and Mr. Johnson
showed a ring that had been dug up
in ruins in the section where formerly the Phoenicians were lords
and masters. Numerous pictures
showing Roman architecture and
highways, denoting the spread of
the Roman Empire over Northern
Africa, were shown.
For the greater part of the last
five years Mr. Johnson has been
engaged in original research, exploration and archxological work
in Tunisia.

Penn. an Easy Mark.

Pennsylvania was easily outclassed by Hopkins on Saturday,
April ii, at Homewood—the score
being 12 to I.
Penn is a newcomer at the Indian game, this being its second
season on the field. Taking this
fact into consideration, its squad
made a good showing.
Troxell shot'the first goal after
about a minute of play, and in the
first half Hopkins kept up a fusillade of shots that resulted in eleven
goals.
Only once did the visitors shoot
the ball past Goalkeeper Sears.
Leslie Tattersall, a Baltimore boy
at Penn, made the lone tally.
Hopkins did not play offensively
in .the second period. A number of
"bench-warmers" — most of them
freshmen from the City College—
were put in the game in the second
